subject: Art
title: Visual Hierarchy Basics
description: Organizing information so viewers process it in the right order.

hook.text: A newspaper has a headline, a subheadline, body text, and captions ‚Äî each progressively smaller and less prominent. That's visual hierarchy: organizing information by importance.

buildup.text: Hierarchy tools: size (bigger = more important), contrast (higher contrast = more attention), color (saturated/warm = demands focus), position (top and center = primary), and detail (more detail = more weight).

discovery.text: In art: your focal point is the 'headline.' Supporting elements are 'subheadlines.' Background is 'body text.' Each level gets progressively less visual weight, guiding the viewer from most to least important.

twist.text: When everything is equally prominent, nothing stands out ‚Äî the hierarchy is flat. Flat hierarchy is the visual equivalent of someone SHOUTING EVERY WORD AT EQUAL VOLUME. It's exhausting and confusing.

climax.text: In your next composition, assign three levels: primary (one element, maximum impact), secondary (supporting elements, medium impact), tertiary (background, minimum impact). Create clear differences between each level.

punchline.text: If everything is important, nothing is. Visual hierarchy decides what the viewer sees first, second, and third.

quiz.question: What happens when all elements in a composition have equal visual weight?
options: Nothing stands out ‚Äî the hierarchy is flat and confusing
